questions.question: What is the core idea behind machine learning?

options.A: Writing explicit instructions for computers to perform tasks.
options.B: Enabling computers to learn from data without being explicitly programmed.
options.C: Creating static models based on predefined rules.
options.D: Developing complex algorithms for data storage.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a main type of machine learning?

options.A: Supervised Learning
options.B: Unsupervised Learning
options.C: Reinforcement Learning
options.D: Rule-Based Learning

questions.question: In supervised learning, what type of data is used for training?

options.A: Unlabeled data only.
options.B: Labeled data with input features and corresponding output targets.
options.C: Data with only numerical features.
options.D: Data that is randomly generated.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of unsupervised learning?

options.A: To predict future outcomes based on labeled data.
options.B: To discover hidden patterns and structures in unlabeled data.
options.C: To learn through trial and error with a reward system.
options.D: To classify data into predefined categories.

questions.question: What is the key characteristic of reinforcement learning?

options.A: Learning from a teacher who provides correct answers.
options.B: Learning patterns from data without any specific guidance.
options.C: Learning through interaction with an environment and receiving rewards or penalties.
options.D: Learning to classify data based on similarity.

questions.question: What is a 'feature' in the context of machine learning?

options.A: The predicted output of a model.
options.B: An individual measurable property or characteristic of a data point.
options.C: A parameter that the model learns during training.
options.D: A method for evaluating the performance of a model.

questions.question: What is a 'target variable' (or 'label') in supervised learning?

options.A: An input feature used for prediction.
options.B: The output variable that the model is trying to predict.
options.C: A hyperparameter that controls the learning process.
options.D: A measure of the model's error.

questions.question: What is the purpose of splitting a dataset into training and testing sets?

options.A: To train the model on all available data.
options.B: To evaluate the model's performance on unseen data after training.
options.C: To increase the size of the dataset for better training.
options.D: To visualize the data distribution.

questions.question: What is 'overfitting' in machine learning?

options.A: When a model performs poorly on both training and testing data.
options.B: When a model learns the training data too well, including noise, and performs poorly on new data.
options.C: When a model generalizes well to unseen data.
options.D: When the training data is insufficient to learn the underlying patterns.

questions.question: What is 'underfitting' in machine learning?

options.A: When a model performs very well on the training data but poorly on testing data.
options.B: When a model fails to capture the underlying patterns in the training data and performs poorly on both training and testing data.
options.C: When the model is too complex for the amount of data.
options.D: When the learning rate is set too high.

questions.question: What is the 'bias-variance tradeoff' in machine learning?

options.A: The tradeoff between model complexity and training time.
options.B: The tradeoff between the amount of data used for training and testing.
options.C: The tradeoff between a model's tendency to underfit (high bias) and overfit (high variance).
options.D: The tradeoff between precision and recall in classification.

questions.question: What is a 'hyperparameter' in a machine learning model?

options.A: A parameter that the model learns from the data during training.
options.B: A parameter that is set prior to training and controls the learning process.
options.C: An input feature used to make predictions.
options.D: The predicted output of the model.

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'model evaluation' in machine learning?

options.A: To train the model on the entire dataset.
options.B: To assess the performance of a trained model on unseen data.
options.C: To select the features to be used for training.
options.D: To tune the hyperparameters of the model.

questions.question: What is a 'loss function' (or 'cost function') used for in training machine learning models?

options.A: To measure the performance of the model on the testing data.
options.B: To quantify the error between the model's predictions and the actual target values during training.
options.C: To determine the optimal hyperparameters of the model.
options.D: To visualize the learning process.

questions.question: What is 'gradient descent'?

options.A: A method for evaluating the gradient of the loss function on the test set.
options.B: An optimization algorithm used to find the minimum of a function (e.g., the loss function) by iteratively moving in the direction of steepest descent.
options.C: A technique for reducing the dimensionality of the input data.
options.D: A way to prevent overfitting by penalizing large weights.

questions.question: What is the difference between a 'parameter' and a 'hyperparameter' in machine learning?

options.A: Parameters are set before training, while hyperparameters are learned during training.
options.B: Hyperparameters are set before training, while parameters are learned during training.
options.C: Parameters are used for unsupervised learning, while hyperparameters are for supervised learning.
options.D: There is no significant difference between them.

questions.question: What is the goal of 'feature scaling'?

options.A: To select the most important features for the model.
options.B: To transform numerical features to a similar scale, which can improve the performance of some algorithms.
options.C: To create new features from existing ones.
options.D: To convert categorical features into numerical representations.

questions.question: What is 'feature encoding' primarily used for?

options.A: Scaling numerical features.
options.B: Handling missing values in the data.
options.C: Converting categorical features into a numerical format that machine learning algorithms can understand.
options.D: Selecting the most relevant features.

questions.question: What is the machine learning lifecycle?

options.A: A linear process of data collection, model training, and evaluation.
options.B: An iterative process that includes problem definition, data collection, data preparation, model selection, training, evaluation, and deployment.
options.C: A one-time process of building a machine learning model.
options.D: The period from when a model is deployed until it becomes obsolete.

questions.question: Why is interpretability sometimes important in machine learning models?

options.A: It always leads to higher accuracy.
options.B: It allows humans to understand how the model makes decisions, which is crucial in sensitive applications like healthcare or finance.
options.C: It simplifies the model development process.
options.D: It is only important for very simple models like linear regression.
